The microstructure of the catalyst influences the electronic states and acid-base properties, allowing for the selective modulation of the catalytic mechanism and substrate conversion pathways, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the target products. In this work, two catalysts, low P-doped Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and high P-doped Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, were synthesized by tuning the amount of non-metallic phosphorus doping in WO3-SiO2. These catalysts exhibited distinct catalytic pathways and product selectivity for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of δ-furfurylidenelevulinic acid (FDLA), a biomass-derived platform molecular condensation intermediate. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that high P doping induced the formation of a WO3-PO4 structure, which provided strong Brønsted acid sites. These sites facilitated the cleavage of the C4-O bond during lactone ring opening and selectively preserved the carboxyl functional group, yielding 56.64 % decanoic acid (DA). By contrast, low P-doped catalysts retained the WO3 structure rich in Lewis acid sites but lacking Brønsted acid sites, leading to the lactone via hydrogenolysis to break the C1-O bond first, followed by dehydration reaction at the Lewis acid sites, thus favoring the production of deeply deoxygenated products (DDPs). A moderate amount of water promoted proton transfer in the HDO process, and adding 8 mg of water increased the DA yield to 66.1 %. The as-prepared catalyst demonstrated acceptable stability during recycling, maintaining a DA yield of 46.64 % after four cycles. Non-metallic phosphorus doping provides a viable strategy for modifying the electronic structure and acid-site properties of catalysts, enabling the selective retention of oxygen-containing functional groups in biomass condensation intermediates. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biomass Furfural Levulinic acid Selective hydrodeoxygenation P-doped catalysts Decanoic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic conversion of renewable biomass into fine chemicals via hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an excellent approach to reduce dependence on fossil resources and establish a sustainable chemical industry [1,2]. Lignocellulosic biomass, the only renewable organic carbon source in nature, is regarded as the most promising organic substitute for fossil feedstocks [3,4]. The strategy of subjecting high-carbon intermediates derived from C-C coupling reactions of lignocellulose-based biomass platform molecules to HDO has been widely used to produce biofuels and high-value chemicals [4,5]. Among these, furfural and levulinic acid are two of the most versatile and promising building block chemicals that can be utilized as the frequently used precursors for the catalytic synthesis of a variety of value-added chemicals and fuel candidates [6]. Currently, most of the aldol condensates (δ-furfurylidenelevulinic acid, FDLA) of furfural and levulinic acid are utilized for producing alkane fuels [7,8]. However, producing medium-chain fatty acids from FDLA is considered a promising approach, as medium-chain fatty acids possess broader applications and higher value [9]. To date, only homogeneous metal triflate (i.e., M(OTf)n) has been reported to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of FDLA to decanoic acid [9]. Therefore, selectively breaking C-O to remove furan oxygen and carbonyl oxygen while preserving carboxyl oxygen on heterogeneous catalysts remains a challenge. Generally, the HDO reaction proceeds over metal/acid bifunctional catalysts rich in metal sites and acidic sites [10]. Notably, the deoxygenation step primarily occurs at acidic sites and is closely associated with the nature and concentration of these acidic sites [11]. For instance, previous studies have reported that Lewis acid sites (LAS) facilitate hydrogenolysis reactions, whereas Brønsted acid sites (BAS) play a critical role in hydrodehydration and hydrodemethoxylation reactions [12]. However, conventional metal/acid bifunctional catalysts have inherent limitations in achieving selective deoxygenation [13,14], particularly for biomass-derived substrates with diverse oxygen-containing functional groups (hydroxyl, carbonyl, carboxyl, furan ring). Specifically, these catalysts cannot selectively cleave or retain specific oxygen-containing functional groups during biomass upgrading, leading to the removal of all such groups [7,15–19]. On the one hand, commonly used metal/acid bifunctional catalysts exhibit strong hydrogenation ability toward CC and C-O bonds, which are prevalent in biomass-derived compounds, leading to deep or complete deoxygenation [14,20]. On the other hand, harsh reaction conditions (e.g., high temperatures or pressures) are often necessary to achieve high conversion and product selectivity [20], but exacerbating the uncontrollability of the HDO process. Fundamentally, catalytic selectivity depends on the nature of the metal centers and acidic supports, as well as the corresponding metal-support interactions [21,22]. Specifically, the catalyst's structure determines its electronic states and acid-base properties, which allow for tuning the catalytic process to target specific chemical bonds/functional groups [10,23,24]. Thus, understanding the microstructure and synergistic mechanisms is crucial for modulating the catalytic process and enhancing the selectivity of the target product. Doping transition metal and/or heteroatoms optimizes catalytic activity and enhances target product selectivity by altering the catalyst's coordination environment and acid-base active sites [25–29]. This approach is regarded as an effective strategy to regulate the properties of heterogeneous catalysts in catalytic reactions. Doping transition metals like W and Co have been proven effective in modulating HDO reaction pathways and product selectivity. Specifically, W/Co doping forms a surface layer that induces electron transfer from the doped atoms to the catalyst matrix, reducing the electron density, which ultimately affects substrate adsorption patterns and binding energies on the catalyst surface, thereby modulating the catalytic pathway and product selectivity [30–35]. For instance, W-doped Mo₂C formed a W-covered layer that promoted electron transfer from W to Mo₂C, enhancing guaiacol adsorption on the MoWC surface, which facilitated direct deoxygenation to form aromatics rather than cyclohydrogenation[34]. Beyond metals, heteroatom doping (e.g., N, P, B) mostly increases electron density on metal nanoparticle surfaces by modulating metal-support interactions, promoting substrate adsorption and selective product desorption [36–38]. Meanwhile, heteroatom doping generates numerous defects and electron-deficient sites, which not only modulate hydrogen spillover behavior but also act as proton/electron acceptors (i.e., Brønsted/Lewis acid sites) to activate and cleave specific oxygen-containing functional groups in substrates, thus regulating reaction depth and product selectivity [38,39]. For example, N-doped Co/C catalysts enhanced Co-C support interactions, increasing the surface electron density of Co nanoparticles, which facilitated vanillin (VAN) adsorption and induced selective C-O bond cleavage [38]. P-doping in TiO2 generated abundant defects and Ti⁴⁺ electron-deficient sites, enhancing hydrogen spillover and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural adsorption. Additionally, Brønsted acid sites induced by hydrogen spillover promoted selective activation and cleavage of C-O bonds [39]. Based on these findings, we proposed tailoring the microelectronic structure and acid-active sites of the catalysts by adjusting non-metallic P doping levels to modulate HDO reaction pathways and product selectivity. Herein, two catalysts, low P-doped Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and high P-doped Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, were prepared by tuning the P doping amount in WO3-SiO2, confirming the differentiated catalyst structures and acid-site properties regulated the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction pathways and product selectivity during the HDO of the biomass-platform molecular condensation intermediate δ-furfurylidenelevulinic acid (FDLA). The facilitating effect of moderate water addition on the FDLA HDO process was also explored. These findings provided valuable guidance for designing selective HDO routes for various biomass condensation intermediates and tailoring catalysts for product modulation. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Preparation of FDLA 36.0 g of Na2CO3 was added to 150 mL of deionized water to neutralize 27.8 g of levulinic acid at room temperature. The solution was heated to reflux with stirring, followed by the addition of a mixture of 11.52 g furfural in 24 mL of ethanol. The solution was cooled in an ice-water bath after confirming the absence of furfural residue. The cooled solution was slowly poured into an excess of dilute hydrochloric acid to precipitate the solid condensation product, which was collected by filtration. FDLA was obtained via recrystallization and stored under dry and light-protected conditions. The successful synthesis of FDLA was confirmed by ¹H NMR spectroscopy (Figure S1). 2.2 Preparation of Pd/xW-yP-SiO2 catalysts (NH4)6W12O40•xH2O (0, 0.375, 0.75, 1.5, 2.25, 3, 4.5, 6 mmol), (NH4)2HPO4 (0, 0.09375,0.1875, 0.375, 0.75, 1.125, 1.5, 2.25, 3 mmol) and citric acid (3 mmol) were dissolved in 3 mL aqueous solution. The mixture was stirred for 1 h at room temperature and then added dropwise to SiO2 (1.2 g). The obtained glue-like sample was dried overnight in an oven at 397 K, followed by calcination at 773 K in a muffle furnace for 5 h at a heating rate of 5 K/min. The calcined samples were denoted xW-yP-SiO2(where x and y represent the number of moles of W and P, respectively). The initial impregnation method was then employed to prepare Pd/xW-yP-SiO2. Specifically, an HCl aqueous solution containing PdCl2 was added to xW-yP-SiO2. The obtained samples were dried in an oven at 397 K overnight and subsequently reduced in H2 at 323 K for 3 h with a flow rate of 75 cm³ /min. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired using a Philips PW3040/60 diffractometer with CuK α radiation (λ= 0.1541 nm), scanned from 5 to 80° at a rate of 10° min−1. NMR spectra of the solutions were recorded on a Bruker AM 600 spectrometer, operating at 600 MHz for 1H at room temperature. 31P NMR measurements were carried on a Bruker AVANCE NEO 400 M, with acquisition parameters including a 3.9 ms pulse length (90° flip angle) and 60 s recycle delay. Chemical shifts were expressed in parts per million using 85 % H3PO4 as an external standard. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were recorded in the 4000–400 cm−1 range using a Thermo Fisher (USA) spectrometer. Raman spectra were obtained on a Renishaw Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser excitation wavelength. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) images, and the corresponding EDX spectra were acquired using a Talos F200X high-resolution TEM operating at 200 kV. Samples were diluted in cyclohexane and sonicated for 10 min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha using a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source, with binding energies calibrated to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Lewis and Brønsted acid sites were determined via pyridine infrared (Py-IR) spectroscopy (Bruker Tensor 27, Germany), with spectra recorded at a desorption temperature of 130 °C. H2-TPR and H2-TPD tests were conducted on an AutoChem II 2920 using a 10 % H2/Ar flow (50 mL min−1), with temperature ramping from 298 to 973 K at 5.0 K min−1. Palladium content in the catalyst was measured by ICP-OES (Agilent 5110, USA). DRIFT spectroscopy studies were performed using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer equipped with a high-sensitivity MCT detector (with a resolution of 4 cm−1). The reduced catalyst (Pd/xW-yP-SiO2) with a mass of 20 mg was pretreated in the presence of 10 % H2/Ar at 483 K for 1 h. Following pretreatment, a background was scanned in He at 293 K, and spectra were then recorded in a GVL/He mixture at 293 K. Background and spectra were obtained at 4 cm−1 resolution of with 32 accumulation scans. 2.4 Catalytic performance and product analysis The catalytic performance of Pd/xW-yP-SiO2 catalysts was evaluated in a 50 mL Teflon-lined magnetically stirred autoclave. For a typical FDLA HDO test, 100 mg of substrate, 50 mg of catalyst, and 10 mL of cyclohexane solvent were charged to the reactor. The reactor was purged with H2 at least five times and then charged with H2 to the desired pressure at room temperature. The reaction was conducted at various temperatures for a specified duration with stirring at 600 rpm. Upon completion of the reaction, the organic products were collected by centrifugation and analyzed qualitatively using a gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (Agilent 7890 B-5977A, HP-5 capillary column) and quantitatively using a gas chromatograph (GC-7980 2014 C, HP-5 column) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). Dodecane was used as an internal standard for quantifying HDO products. Conversion and yield were calculated using the following equations: Conversion % = moles of reacted substrate moles of initial substrate × 100 % Yield % = moles of formed produced moles of initial substrate × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Hydrodeoxygenation of FDLA The condensation product FDLA was selected as the reaction substrate to evaluate the HDO activity and product selectivity of the catalysts with different P doping levels. The HDO product distribution of FDLA catalyzed by the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst at 130 °C and 3 MPa and varying reaction times is shown in Fig. 1a. During the reaction, the ring-containing 5-(2-(tetrahydrofuran-2-yl)ethyl)-dihydrofuran-2(3 H)-one (DC) and γ-decalactone, the ring-opening decanoic acid (DA), and the deeply deoxygenated products (DDPs, including decanoic alcohol, decanoic ether, decanoic ester, decane and nonane) were detected (Figure S2). Lactonization dominated the initial reaction stage, with γ-decalactone achieving a maximum yield of 47.18 % at 2 h, followed by its gradual conversion to DA and DDPs. Thus, the γ-decalactone was the intermediate in FDLA transformation to DA and DDPs. The DA yield peaked at 56.48 % at 12 h, after which prolonged reaction time led to a decrease in DA yield, while the yields of decane, decanoic ether, decanoic ester, and nonane continued to increase, indicating deep deoxygenation of DA. Thus, one plausible pathway for DA formation involved hydrolysis of γ-decalactone catalyzed by Brønsted acid sites, which cleaved the C4-O bond [40] (Fig. 1c, pathway 1). In contrast, decanoic alcohol could be generated via either the deep hydrogenation of DA or the hydrogenation of γ-decalactone to break the C1-O bond, followed by dehydration (Fig. 1c, pathway 2). The obtained decanoic alcohol and DA are further converted to decanoic ether, decanoic ester, and alkanes through esterification/etherification and cascade HDO reactions. Under identical reaction conditions, the FDLA HDO product distribution over the Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 followed a trend similar to that of Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 1b). Notably, distinct catalyst structures induced different product selectivity. The high P-doped catalysts favored pathway 1 to obtain 56.48 % DA yield, whereas the low P-doped catalysts tended to yield > 60 % DDPs via pathway 2. To explore the origin of reaction propensity differences between the two catalysts, component roles were first investigated ( Table 1). FDLA was almost converted by Pd and/or W and/or P species at elevated temperatures. For instance, no FDLA was detected in the organic phase after the HDO reaction. Besides, no cracked light alkanes were observed in the gas products. However, the carbon balance of cyclohexane liquid products catalyzed by catalysts lacking Pd, W, or P was less than 50 % (Entries 1–9). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of spent catalysts revealed significant mass loss in the 200–500 °C range, indicating coke formation on the catalyst surface. Notably, the spent Pd/1W-1P-SiO2 catalyst exhibited no considerable mass loss even at temperatures up to 900 °C, indicating minimal coking during the reaction and a carbon balance of 94.67 % (Table 1 and Figure S3). Thereby, the carbon loss could be related to the formation of coke. No hydrogenation products were detected over the Pd-free catalysts, confirming that Pd NPs are indispensable for hydrogenation (Entries 6–8). Simple oxide catalysts such as Pd/Al2O3, Pd/ZrO2, Pd/TiO2, Pd/WO3 and Pd/SiO2 exhibit limited HDO activity, with minimal preliminary HDO products DC and γ-decalactone, attributed to the absence of acidic active sites for deoxygenation (Entries 1–5). Introducing W enhanced the conversion of DC to γ-decalactone on Pd/1W-SiO2 (Entry 9). The P doping enabled the detection of the subsequent lactone ring-opening products (DA and DDPs) (Entries 10 and 11), indicating that P doping facilitates catalytic C-O bond cleavage in the lactone ring. Therefore, the P-O derived Brønsted acidity synergizes with the hydrogenation capacity of Pd to overcome the lactone ring-opening barriers. Reaction conditions: FDLA (100 mg, 0.515 mmol), cyclohexane (10 mL), metal catalyst (50 mg), 3 MPa H2 at room temperature, 130 °C, stirred at 600 rpm, 12 h. The effects of W and P loadings on the FDLA HDO activity were conducted (Fig. 1d, e). Notably, increasing W loading from 0 to 4 mmol exhibited a volcano-shaped trend in DA yield and total carbon balance (Figure 1d, S4a). The optimal HDO activity occurred at a W loading of 1.5 mmol, where DA yield reached 56.48 % and carbon balance attained 99.68 %. The γ-decalactone dominated below 1.5 mmol W, whereas excessive W (>1.5 mmol) induced catalyst coking, evidenced by a carbon balance decrease (<80 %). At a fixed W loading (1.5 mmol), P doping effects on FDLA HDO activity were shown in Figure 1e, S4b. Both extremely low (W/P > 12) and high (W/P < 1) P loadings were detrimental to HDO, with DA yields < 30 % due to insufficient or excessive acidity. Within the P loading range of 0.09875–3 mmol (W/P = 24–1), the catalyst exhibits superior DA selectivity compared to DDPs. Conversely, when W/P > 6, DDPs selectivity exceeds 60 %. 3.2 Catalyst characterization To understand the reasons behind the differences in catalytic activity and production selectivity caused by the P content, a series of catalysts with varying P doping levels were characterized. X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra of commercial SiO2 support (ICDD 20–0085) exhibited a distinct broad peak at 2θ = 20–25° [41], characteristic of an amorphous material. A new diffraction signal at 33.9° was assigned to the Pd (101) plane in the Pd/SiO2 catalyst [42]. The disappearance of Pd species' characteristic peaks indicated that the introduction of W and P species promoted the dispersion of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) ( Fig. 2a). Notably, crystallographic structure variation showed a strong correlation with P doping level. Pd, W and P elemental contents in representative Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalysts determined by ICP were shown in Table S1. For low P-doped supports, the characteristic peaks of WO3 (ICDD 20–1324) appeared at 23.7° and 33.6° [43,44], whereas high P-doped supports exhibited amorphous features, suggesting that high-content P doping induced WO₃ amorphization via lattice distortion. Interestingly, the low P-doped catalyst not only retained the WO3 characteristic peaks but also displayed weak Keggin-type phosphotungstic acid (HPW) diffraction peaks (ICDD 50–0304) at 10.3°, 12.9°, 13.6°, 20.7°, and 37.6° [42,45] after Pd impregnation. In contrast, high P-doped catalysts showed only enhanced HPW diffraction signals (Figure 2b and S5). These results indicated that P doping induced the Keggin-type HPW formation during Pd NPs loading, confirming the key role of P doping in regulating the structural transition of the catalyst. To characterize the P species and confirm HPW formation, the representative Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalysts were analyzed by solid 31P NMR (Fig. 2c, d). As shown in Fig. 2c and d, the resonance signal at δ = -15.6 ppm indicated the presence of the Keggin-type HPW in both catalysts [46], while the signal near δ = -11.19 ppm corresponded to WO3-PO4 glasses [46,47]. Convolution of the 31P NMR profiles revealed the WO3-PO4/HPW ratios of 3.86 for Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and 18.12 for Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2. Combined with XRD results, these results confirmed that P doping modulated structural transitions. In low P-doped catalysts, the active components consist of WO3 with trace amounts of Keggin-type HPW and amorphous WO3-PO4 phases. Conversely, high P doping disrupted WO3 crystallinity, promoting the formation of amorphous WO3-PO4 phases. These findings highlighted the critical role of the P doping level in regulating the transformation between crystalline WO3 and amorphous WO3-PO4 structures. As shown in Fig. 2e and f, the morphology of Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalysts were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Lattice fringes with an interplanar d-spacing of 0.22 nm corresponded to the (111) plane of Pd in both catalysts [48]. Additionally, the particle sizes of Pd NPs were comparable between the two catalysts. Notably, a distinctive lattice fringe with a d-spacing of 0.37 nm was assigned to the (020) plane of WO3 in the 1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst [49,50]. However, the absence of lattice fringes associated with HPW and WO3-PO4 was observed in both catalysts, which might be attributed to the electron beam intolerance of HPW organic crystals or their coverage by amorphous SiO2 layers [51]. On the other hand, the results validated that the WO3-PO4 phase did not form a crystalline lattice. Furthermore, distinct diffraction rings were assigned to the (020), (221) and (002) planes of WO3 in the 1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst [52], whereas the single-crystal diffractogram of the Keggin structure of HPW in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst was clearly detected [53]. The absence of the WO3-PO4 diffraction signature in both systems confirmed the conclusions derived from XRD regarding the amorphous nature of the WO3-PO4 phase. Complementary analyses confirmed that the amount of P doping modulated the structural transition of the catalyst from crystalline WO3 to amorphous WO3- PO4. The structural variations of the catalysts modulated by the amount of P doping were further analyzed using FTIR and Raman spectroscopy. The vibrational signals at 982 cm−1 and 888 cm−1 for all the catalysts were attributed to the stretching vibrations of WO and W-O-W [54], respectively (Figure S6). However, the characteristic peaks of P-O were obscured by SiO2. To circumvent this issue, silica-free samples were prepared, and their FTIR spectra confirmed that the peak at 1082 cm−1 was ascribed to PO4 tetrahedra (Figure S7a). Notably, unique peaks in the 1000–1200 cm−1 region emerged in the Pd/1.5W-1P catalyst, which were assigned to the stretching vibrations of the P-O bond in inorganic phosphate compounds [55]. These peaks distinctly differed from the asymmetric P-O stretching peak of PW12O40 3- ions, which appeared solely at 1082 cm−1. In the Raman spectra, the peak centered at 783 cm−1 in the Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst was associated with the vibration of the W-O-W band [56], whereas this peak was shifted to 792 cm−1 in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst. Two additional peaks at 901 and 937 cm−1 emerged in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst, which were ascribed to the bond vibrations of the terminal oxygen atom (WO or W-O-) associated with the W atom in the WO6 octahedra [57] (Figure S7b). The results indicated that the WO3-PO4 glass structure was composed of inter-connected PO4 tetrahedra and WO6 octahedra linked by W-O-P bridges. 3.3 Insights into catalytic performance To gain a deeper understanding of the relationship between catalyst structure and product selectivity, the compositions and chemical valence states of different species on these catalysts surface were first analyzed using XPS technology. For Pd 3d, two sets of spin-orbit splitting peaks (3d₃/₂ and 3d₅/₂) at 335.1/336.8 eV and 340.3/342.6 eV were observed, corresponding to Pd0 and Pd2+ [42], respectively ( Fig. 3a). Reduced Pd0 was dominant in all catalysts, which facilitated H2 adsorption and dissociation in the HDO reaction. According to the results of P2p results, PO4 3- tetrahedral coordination was the predominant form in the catalyst [58,59]. The intensity variations of P2p1/2 and 2p3/2 components, generated by spin-orbit splitting, indicated the prevalence of an amorphous-phase PO4 structure in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst [58,60], consistent with 31P NMR, FTIR, and Raman findings. The electron binding energy of P(V)2 P decreased upon Pd loading but increased after W introduction, suggesting partial electron transfer from Pd to P and then to W. In the W-SiO2 sample, the peaks at 35.8 and 37.9 eV were assigned to W 4 f7/2 and 4 f5/2, corresponding to W6+ [42,61]. All Pd-containing catalysts exhibited new peaks at ∼34.8 and 36.8 eV, attributed to W5+, indicating a mixed W5+/W6+ oxidation state in Pd/1.5W-yP-SiO2 (Fig. 3a). Notably, the Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst contained more W6+, whereas the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst showed the opposite trend, suggesting that high P doping promoted W6+ reduction to W5+. The O 1 s peaks at 530.2, 532.9, and 534.6 eV were assigned to lattice oxygen in metal oxides, surface hydroxyl oxygen in SiO2, and physically adsorbed water [62], respectively (Figure S8). The significantly weakened lattice oxygen intensity in Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 confirmed the catalyst's amorphous structure. The NH3-TPD technique was employed to probe the available surface acidity of the catalysts. Figure S9 presented the NH3-TPD profiles of the different catalysts from 50 to 700 ℃. The desorption peaks below 250 °C，in the regions of 250–400 °C and > 400 °C, correspond to NH3 desorption from weak acid sites, medium-strong acid sites and strong acid sites on the catalyst surface, respectively [63,64]. No NH3 desorption was detected on pure SiO2, indicating it has no acidity. The 1P-SiO2 catalyst exhibited a single desorption peak at 120 °C, corresponding to weak acid sites, with an acid content of 1039.15 μmol/g. The 1.5W-SiO2 catalyst showed two desorption peaks at 95 °C and 551 °C, assigned to weak and strong acid sites, respectively. Their acid contents were 230.56 and 183.28 μmol/g, with a total acidity of 413.84 μmol/g. In contrast, Pd/SiO2 displayed four distinct desorption peaks at 95 °C, 245 °C, 381 °C, and 521 °C. These peaks correspond to two types of weak acid sites, one medium-strong acid site, and one strong acid site on the catalyst surface, with a total acidity of 1266.06 μmol/g. These results confirmed that P species primarily provided weak acid sites, W species supplied both weak and strong acid sites, and Pd species contributed all three types of acid sites. When comparing 1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 with 1.5W-1P-SiO2, and Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 with Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, the acid active site distribution and total acid content of the two catalyst groups were found to be comparable (Table S2). Furthermore, spectroscopic techniques for probing molecular adsorption have been employed to characterize the nature, strength and concentration of acidic sites in solid catalysts. Pyridine adsorption infrared technology (Py-FTIR) was performed to identify Brønsted acidic sites (BAS) and Lewis acidic sites (LAS) via their vibrational signals. As shown in Fig. 3b, the spectral features at 1540–1536 cm−1, 1454–1445 cm−1 and 1488–1485 cm−1 were assigned to pyridine adsorbed on BAS, LAS, and mixed BAS/LAS sites [65], respectively. No acidic characteristic peaks were detected on the SiO2 support. Following P doping, distinct BAS and mixed LAS/BAS peaks emerged, whereas W introduction exclusively showed LAS, indicating that P sites primarily contributed to BAS and mixed acid sites, while W sites predominantly provided LAS. Additionally, Pd sites generated extra LAS in the catalysts. Convolution of the Py-IR curves revealed that P doping modulated the BAS/LAS ratio (Table S3). Specifically, the BAS/LAS ratio of the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst was 5.7-fold higher than that of Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2, which may correlate with the highly polarized P-O sites in the amorphous WO3-PO4 structure [39]. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted to probe the redox behavior and metal-support interactions of the P-doped catalysts (Fig. 3c). A distinct negative peak at 65 °C in all samples was possibly assigned to the formation of PdHx via the decomposition of chemisorbed H2 on Pd monomers [66]. For catalysts with varying P doping levels, three reduction peaks were observed: the high-temperature reduction of W6+ to W0 (640–650 °C) [67,68], the medium-temperature reduction of W6+ to W5+ (310–520 °C), and the low-temperature activation of P-O bonds (300–400 °C) [69]. Notably, P doping lowered the reduction temperature of Pd oxides compared to P-free catalysts, indicating that Pd-P-W electronic interactions enhanced reducibility, which contributed to the catalysts' excellent HDO performance under mild conditions. Furthermore, H2-TPD was employed to characterized the hydrogen activation capability of typical catalysts with varying P loadings in selective HDO reactions (Fig. 3d). Two low temperatures (<200 °C) desorption peaks were observed, corresponding to the physically adsorbed H2 on Pd metal and the weak chemisorption at the supports interface (WO3 or WO3-PO4) [70]. In contrast, the peaks above 400 °C were attributed to hydrogen spillover associated with catalyst supports [13]. The lower peak intensity in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst at high temperatures indicated diminished hydrogen spillover [13], leading to a reduced hydrogenolysis ability of the 1.5W-1P-SiO2 support during the HDO process, achieving the selectively preserving the more difficult-to-deoxygenate carboxyl groups. Furthermore, the different hydrogen spillover behaviors were diagnosed by monitoring the color change of WO3 under the H2 atmosphere in the presence of the catalyst [71]. As shown in Figure S10, both catalysts induced color changes, but Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 produced a darker hue than Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, indicating hydrogen spillover occurred on both systems. The spillover was more pronounced on Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2, aligning with H2-TPD results and matching well with activity data. To investigate the influence of HPW in the two catalysts on the FDLA HDO reaction pathway and product selectivity, Pd/HPW-SiO2-500 and Pd/HPW-SiO2-0 were prepared as control catalysts. The commercially available HPW (W/P = 12) was used to replace the P/W precursor with or without calcination treatment. The calcined Pd/HPW-SiO2-500 exhibited a WO3 crystalline structure, analogous to low-P-doped catalysts, whereas the uncalcined Pd/HPW-SiO2-0 retained characteristic diffraction peaks of Keggin-type HPW (Figure S11). The solid 31P NMR results further confirmed the coexistence of HPW and WO3-PO4 in Pd/HPW- SiO2-500 (Figure S12a), while only Keggin-type HPW was detected in Pd/HPW- SiO2-0 (Figure S12b). When applied to FDLA HDO, Pd/HPW-SiO2-500 showed significantly higher selectivity for DDPs (66.45 % yield). Notably, Pd/HPW-SiO2-0 catalyzed a lower DA yield (41.99 %) than Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, along with 22.84 % γ-decalactone and an 83.9 % carbon balance (Figure 3e and S13). These results laterally confirmed the irreplaceable role of the WO3-PO4 structure in high-P-doped catalysts for DA generation from FDLA. γ-Decalactone serves as a critical intermediate, with its ring-opening pathway influencing product selectivity during FDLA HDO. Given the structural similarity between γ-valerolactone (GVL) and γ-decalactone, GVL was employed as a probe molecule in situ diffuse reflectance infrared (DRIFT) spectroscopy to elucidate the adsorption activation mechanisms of catalysts with varying P loadings. All catalysts were first subjected to pre-reduction, followed by the introduction of GVL-saturated vapor into the sample cell. As shown in Figure S14, GVL adsorption on all catalysts yielded analogous DRIFT spectra after adsorption stabilization, indicating identical primary adsorption sites. The positive bands in the spectra are assigned to adsorbed GVL, whereas the negative bands are associated with surface species consumed by the interaction with the GVL [72]. The negative band of νOH at 3740 cm−1 demonstrated the participation of terminal silanol groups on the SiO2 support in GVL interaction [72]. Absorption bands in the range of νCH (3000–2850 cm−1), νCO (1900–1650 cm−1) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) ring (1250–950 cm−1) confirmed the intact adsorption of GVL on the surface of the catalyst [72]. Notably, a unique weak absorption band at 1674 cm−1in the Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst was attributed to the carbonyl adsorption of GVL on the electron-deficient Lewis acid sites derived from WO3 [73] (Figure S15). In contrast, when GVL was adsorbed on bare SiO2 and Pd/SiO2, the vibrational signals of CO and the THF ring were only observed after 10 min, indicating that GVL adsorbs more readily on Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 (Figure S14 c,d ). Following He purging to switch the gas to H₂/Ar for the reaction phase, all absorption bands decreased with increasing temperature due to the desorption of adsorbed GVL from the catalyst surface ( Fig. 4a, b). Notably, the breathing vibration intensity of the THF ring near 944 cm−1 on Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 was significantly lower than that on Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2. According to the literature, the lower intensity may arise from strong interactions between ring electrons and surface hydroxyl groups [74], suggesting the lactone ring interacts more strongly with Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, facilitating ring activation. The THF ring vibration signal was weakened on Pd/SiO2 or even absent on bare SiO2, maybe due to the weak adsorption of the THF ring leading to desorption during the purging stage (Figure S16). Similarly, the carbonyl vibrational peak of the lactone ring kept moving to lower wavenumbers from the original position at 1760 cm−1 with increasing temperature, indicating the continuous activation of the carbonyl group at the catalyst surface [42]. Concurrently, the diminishing negative stretching vibration peak of the hydroxyl group at 3740 cm−1 reflected the progression of carbonyl group hydrogenation. Furthermore, three vibrational signals in the 2800–3000 cm−1 range were assigned to CH3, CH2, and CH groups [75], respectively (Fig. 4c, d). On bare SiO2, all C-H vibration signals gradually disappear as the increasing temperature. On Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2, the peak at 2985 cm−1 (CH3) intensified significantly more than the peak at 2939 cm−1 (CH2) with temperature, whereas on Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 and Pd/SiO2, the ν(CH3) band at 2985 cm−1 and the ν(CH2) band at 2936 cm−1 showed similar intensities. The enhanced ν(CH2) band on Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 indicates that adsorbed GVL undergoes C4–O bond cleavage to form species with more CH2 groups, converting GVL to valeric acid via Path 1 in Fig. 4e (generating three CH2 groups from two) [72]. Conversely, GVL on Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 may follow Path 2 in Fig. 4e, yielding intermediates retaining two CH2 groups. Comparative experiments between the two catalysts were performed at 130 °C, 3 MPa, and 4 h using GVL and γ-decalactone as substrates to validate the reaction pathways and product selectivity modulated by catalyst active components. For GVL conversion over Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, pentanoic acid and pentyl pentanoate were detected, whereas extra DDPs (pentyl ether and pentane) were observed over Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 (Figure S17). In the HDO products of γ-decalactone, the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst predominantly formed decane, DA, and decanoic ester with only trace amounts of decanoic ether. Conversely, the Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 catalyst produced moderate amounts of 2-n-hexyltetrahydrofuran and decanoic alcohol, along with significant yields of decanoic ether (Figure S18). Additionally, the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst displayed superior catalytic performance in GVL and γ-decalactone conversion, with enhanced fatty acid selectivity (Table S4 and S5). These results confirmed that highly P-doped catalysts selectively cleave the C4-O bond of the lactone ring to afford fatty acids. Based on the above characterization results, the FDLA HDO mechanism over high-P-doped catalysts was proposed in Fig. 4f, g. The Pd sites facilitated the H2 adsorption and dissociation, generating reactive hydrogen species (H*) that preferentially hydrogenated the unsaturated moieties (double bonds, ketocarbonyls, and furan rings) of FDLA to saturate the double bonds and furan ring, reduce ketocarbonyls to hydroxyl groups, which then underwent intramolecular dehydration at acidic sites to form DC. Following the HDO of DC's furan ring, γ-decalactone was yielded [7]. Owing to the abundant Brønsted acidic sites provided by the WO3-PO4 structure in high-P-doped catalysts, the C4-O bond of γ-decalactone was preferentially cleaved to form an (E)-dec-3-enoic acid intermediate, which undergoes hydrogenation to produce DA. In contrast, on low-P catalysts, hydrogenolysis-induced ring-opening preferentially cleaves the C1-O bond. Subsequent rapid dehydration at strong Lewis acid sites provided by WO₃ yields 2-n-hexyltetrahydrofuran, which undergoes further hydrogenolysis-induced ring-opening to produce decanoic alcohol ultimately. The detection of 2-n-hexyltetrahydrofuran catalyzed by Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 confirmed the occurrence of this reaction pathway (Figure S18). The generated decanoic alcohol could further undergo esterification/etherification or successive HDO to form decanoic ester, decanoic ether and alkanes (Fig. 4g). Therefore, the Brønsted-rich WO3-PO4 structure preferentially cleaves the C4-O bond to produce DA rather than activating the C1-O bond for the formation of DDPs. Optimal lactone ring hydrogenolysis with suppressed deep deoxygenation required precise temperature-pressure balancing. For instance, reducing the reaction temperature to 120 °C and increasing hydrogen pressure to 5 MPa on Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 enhanced DA selectivity to 57.89 %, significantly higher than the 17.07 % DDPs, despite detectable γ-decalactone (Figure S19). Conversely, high-temperature/low-pressure (180 °C/1 MPa) conditions promoted excessive deoxygenation, yielding > 90 % DDPs selectivity (Figure S19). Systematic optimization revealed that Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 at 130 °C/3 MPa for 12 h achieved a peak DA yield of 56.48 %, establishing these as the optimal catalytic conditions (Figure S20). 3.4 Role of H2O in the HDO process Deoxygenation generally involves a dehydration process, thus, the critical role of water in regulating the FDLA HDO reaction was investigated. Adding small amounts of water (<10 mg) increased DA yield from 56.48 % to 66.1 %, whereas adding > 10 mg water decreased DA yield and increased γ-decalactone ( Fig. 5a). On the one hand, this may be attributed to the hydration reaction of W⁶⁺ Lewis acid sites in the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO₂ catalyst in the presence of water, exhibiting Brønsted acid properties, thereby enhancing the DA yield. The result was confirmed by Py-FTIR, which observed a reduction in Lewis acid sites and a significant increase in Brønsted acid sites in the catalyst after water saturation (Figure S21), consistent with previous reports [77,78]. On the other hand, this may result from improved solubility and the formation of a water/cyclohexane two-phase interface, which increases mass transfer resistance, hinders the diffusion of water-insoluble species (e.g., DA), and inhibits deep deoxygenation of DA when moderate water is introduced. Existing studies have confirmed that in the presence of reduced palladium in the aqueous phase, water accelerates hydrogen capture and transfer [79–81]. This finding suggested water promoted hydrogen transfer from the liquid phase to metal and acid sites, facilitating HDO. The mass spectrometry of the DA product after adding D2O showed average molecular weight increased from 172 to 173–174 (Figure S22 and Table S6), confirming water-mediated hydrogen transfer. H2-TPD revealed that water-saturated Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 exhibited a significantly lower H₂ desorption temperature, with the high-temperature desorption peak disappearing (Fig. 5b). The results demonstrated that the most H2 was desorbed at 75.4 °C, indicating excess water hinders HDO. 3.5 Stability test of Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 The reusability of the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst was investigated under optimal reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 5c, the catalyst maintained a desirable catalytic activity, with the DA yields ranging from 56.48 % to 52.42 % in the initial two catalytic cycles. However, after reuse four times, the DA yield decreased to 46.64 %, indicating a slight decline in catalytic activity. TEM characterization of the spent Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalysts revealed the slight aggregation of Pd NP to 8.45 ± 1.61 nm (Fig. 5d). XRD patterns showed new diffraction signals at 40.3°, 46.8°, and 68.3° compared with the fresh catalyst, which were assigned to metallic palladium (ICDD 87–0639) (Fig. 5e), further confirming the aggregation of Pd NPs. Furthermore, the 31P NMR of fresh and spent catalysts showed no difference, suggesting the WO3-PO4 were still the main active component (Fig. 5f), while the HPW XRD diffraction signal weakened (Fig. 5 e), which might be related to the accumulation of water during the cycling tests, as water would dissolve HPW [82]. Meanwhile, the excessive water would inhibit interfacial mass transfer, leading to decreased HDO efficiency after each cycle. The above results indicated that the agglomeration of Pd NPs and water accumulation contributed to the decline in HDO activity of the Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2 catalyst. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, this study successfully achieved the directional preparation of the catalyst structure by regulating the P doping levels, thereby elucidating the HDO conversion pathways and product selectivity modulated by the catalyst structure. The WO3-PO4 active phase formed via high P doping exhibited abundant Brønsted acid sites, favoring C4-O bond cleavage during γ-decalactone ring-opening, thereby selectively preserving the carboxyl functional group and obtaining a higher DA yield. In contrast, the low P-doped catalysts preserved electron-deficient WO3 active phases, whose abundant Lewis acidity tends to cause lactones to undergo hydrogenolysis cleavage of the C1-O bond first, followed by a dehydration pathway to form more DDPs. The water acted as a hydrogen proton carrier to promote hydrogen transfer, thereby enhancing DA yield in the HDO process. This work proposes a non-metallic P-doping strategy for tailoring catalyst structures, enabling selective control over catalytic conversion pathways to produce fatty acids or deep deoxygenation products. This approach facilitates the conversion of biomass resources into high-value chemicals or fuels. coredata.dc:description: The microstructure of the catalyst influences the electronic states and acid-base properties, allowing for the selective modulation of the catalytic mechanism and substrate conversion pathways, thereby enhancing the selectivity of the target products. In this work, two catalysts, low P-doped Pd/1.5W-0.125P-SiO2 and high P-doped Pd/1.5W-1P-SiO2, were synthesized by tuning the amount of non-metallic phosphorus doping in WO3-SiO2. These catalysts exhibited distinct catalytic pathways and product selectivity for the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of δ-furfurylidenelevulinic acid (FDLA), a biomass-derived platform molecular condensation intermediate. Comprehensive characterizations revealed that high P doping induced the formation of a WO3-PO4 structure, which provided strong Brønsted acid sites. These sites facilitated the cleavage of the C4-O bond during lactone ring opening and selectively preserved the carboxyl functional group, yielding 56.64 % decanoic acid (DA). By contrast, low P-doped catalysts retained the WO3 structure rich in Lewis acid sites but lacking Brønsted acid sites, leading to the lactone via hydrogenolysis to break the C1-O bond first, followed by dehydration reaction at the Lewis acid sites, thus favoring the production of deeply deoxygenated products (DDPs). A moderate amount of water promoted proton transfer in the HDO process, and adding 8 mg of water increased the DA yield to 66.1 %. The as-prepared catalyst demonstrated acceptable stability during recycling, maintaining a DA yield of 46.64 % after four cycles. Non-metallic phosphorus doping provides a viable strategy for modifying the electronic structure and acid-site properties of catalysts, enabling the selective retention of oxygen-containing functional groups in biomass condensation intermediates.
coredata.dc:title: Modulation on reaction path and product selectivity by non-metallic P-doped catalysts in hydrodeoxygenation
